Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from 
English with Jennifer. In this lesson,

we're going to talk about inversion. Do 
you know what it means to invert something?

I'll give you a hint. What did I do 
with the hourglass? I inverted it.

When you invert the hourglass, the 
sand pours down into the bottom part.
How about this photo? Can you see it properly?

Probably not. Let me invert it. I'll rotate it 
and put it right side up. Now can you see it?

In grammar, if we invert two parts of a 
sentence, we reverse their positions. You

already know how to do this. We invert the 
subject and verb when we form questions.
Have you ever seen such clear blue water?

Yes, I have. I've seen 
beautiful water in the Bahamas.

We can also invert the subject 
and verb in sentences that use

negative adverbs. We do this when the 
negative adverb is in the initial position.

That means it starts the sentence. We 
don't usually do this in spoken English.

It's more typical of written English because it's 
a more formal structure, so you can expect to see

inversion with negative adverbs more in 
academic writing and literary writing.

Let's practice together. Look at this 
sentence. First, identify the negative adverb.

"Never." Right? We'll move it to the beginning of 
the sentence. Next, we'll switch...we'll invert

the subject and verb. Only the first part of 
the verb. We'll use the helping verb first.

So, what's the new sentence? Never have 
I seen such clear, beautiful water.

Try this one. Start with a negative 
adverb. Invert the subject and verb.

Is there a helping verb? It's 
a modal verb. Put that first.
Then the subject.
And what's our new sentence?

Hardly could I believe that 
such beauty existed underground.
Okay. Next one.
What are we going to start with?
"Seldom." There's no helping verb here,

so we'll need to get one. If we change this 
into a question, what helping verb would we use?
"Do." That's what we need. verb + subject

And what's the new sentence? Seldom do people have 
the time to appreciate nature in our busy world.
Try this one. It's similar to the last one.

Rarely do I have the chance to unplug and enjoy 
complete solitude. Here's your next challenge.
Let me give you a hint. "Not any" changes to "no."

Do you think you have it? Under no circumstances 
should you touch fragile stalactites in a cave.
Here's the last sentence and your final challenge.

Before I give you the answer, I'll explain 
that with conditional sentences that use

"only if" or "only when," we use inversion 
in the main clause not the if-clause.

I see two possible variations. Only if the 
guide tells you it is safe can you take photos

on this tour. Only when the guy tells you 
it is safe can you take photos on this tour.

That's all for now. Please like the video 
if you found it useful and interesting.
